Hi all -

>This approach also suggests that programmers do not have to worry about
>*building* consciousness into a system - it is an *emergent* property of an
>adequately complex adaptive network.

Did any of you listen to the 2003 Reith Lectures given by Professor 
Vilayanur Ramachandran? (You can find them here 
http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio4/reith2003/lecturer.shtml ).

At various points, he discusses consciousness and how certain parts of 
the brain seem to take part in it, but others don't. This of course 
raises the question of why some areas of the brain don't need (or 
generate) consciousness, and why some do, and he does mention the idea 
of listing out all the parts believed to be connected to consciousness 
and those unconnected to it, and seeing if that gives any insight into 
where consciousness originates or what it actually does. (As far as I'm 
aware, nobody has yet made a list like this, although I'd be interested 
to see one if anyone knows of one.)

--Darren
